ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Obviously I learned a bit of Italian (more than one would expect for a one-semester class). I also got to learn a little bit about Italian culture and work on my speaking/presenting skills.
Basic understanding of Italian language; reading, writing, listening, compositions, vocabulary, grammatical structures, and so on.
I learned basic Italian grammar and vocabulary and can now hold a conversation in Italian.
I learned the basics of italian

I learned so much more Italian than I ever anticipated! I have never been great at learning languages, so I was nervous coming into the course. But almost immediately I learned how to have a short conversation. By the end of one semester I have basic communication and comprehension skills - the level of which which took me years of taking a different language in high school to learn.

I'm astounded by my quick growth in Italian over the past semester! Prior to this course, I didn't know a single word in Italian. Now, I'm able to watch films, listen to dialogues, and read in Italian, and generally have an understanding of the plot. I picked up tons of Italian vocabulary and acquired an understanding of grammar (articles, verb tenses, indirect/direct object pronouns, etc.)
I learned so much from this class. You learn the basics needed to speak, read, and write. If I was dropped in ITaly I wouldn't be fluent at all, but I would not be completely lost.
I cant believe how much Italian I learned in a few months, this Professor and course were really great.
I learned how to speak Italian proficiently! I was very surprised how much I leaned in one semester.
A basic understanding of Italian vocabulary, syntax, and culture.
Ive acquired basic listening, reading, writing and speaking skills in Italian. By the end of this course, I was definitely able to hold a basic conversation in Italian.
An introduction to italian
Basic Italian grammar and vocabulary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: Professor Michael Farina is super engaging and supportive, the workload is very consistent so you'll know about how much time you need to spend studying each day the entire semester.
No weaknesses!

Italian with Michael is a ton of fun. There's a lot of vocab to study, but putting in a bit of time every day will give you a good understanding of Italian by the end of the semester. The first few weeks can be tough because the class is taught in Italian but you don't know any yet.
This course was great! The biggest strength was Michael Farina, he is a phenomenal professor and does a very good job of investing in his students.

The biggest strength is Michael. He is an incredibly engaging and energetic professor, and most importantly, he clearly cares about all of his students. He is always there to help and encourage and he makes even the challenges of the course manageable. The course did not have many weaknesses, but at times it did feel like it was going a bit fast. The daily quizzes were also challenging and a bit nerve-wracking at first, but they forced me to keep up with my work which made the course easier in the long run.

Strengths: fast-paced, encourages quick learning, highly engaging/never boring, aligns closely with textbook, daily quizzes to self-assess and ensure we stayed on track 

Weaknesses: would've loved more opportunities for student-student dialogue
I loved everything about this class.
This course gave a broad view of the Italian language and culture. The work directly connected to what was being taught.

The intimate environment of the class and the fact that its everyday truly allowed me to build on my language skills quickly. The choice of exercises, homeworks and everyday quizzes were highly useful.

Really well structured, especially with Michael. DEFINITELY take with him if you can. The only weakness is that you don't necessarily know how you're "doing" in the course. More feedback on our progress might be useful
This course made sure that students studied hard and it was very rewarding!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are truly interested in learning Italian. The Italian department has a reputation for being "easy," but don't confuse supportive/kind for easy. This class, like all L1 languages, can a bit demanding as it requires you to put in work every single day to make sure you're staying afloat (missing class makes it easy to fall behind if you don't stay on top of the reading). So if you're interested in this class to get an easy A, there are better options. But if you want to learn Italian (and probably still get an A if you're willing to work hard), then this is a great class.
YES!!!
Italian is a great class, especially if you have Michael. The workload isn't bad and you'll learn so much and have a lot of fun.
Yes!! Especially with Farina

Yes! Italian is a fun language to learn and if you are going to do so, you should definitely take the course with Michael. Even the hard parts of the class were fun and I looked forward to it every morning.

I would recommend this course to another student, as long as this student is committed to learning Italian! This course requires a high level of commitment, but the learning environment is very friendly and comfortable.
I have not taken another language at Yale, but I would suggest the italian dept to anyone who asked purely because of this class.
Absolutely
Absolutely. Michael is the best professor.
Yes, our professor was kind and cared much about our education. He truly ignited a passion for Italian in me.

I would definitely recommend this course to a student interested in learning Italian. It is very rewarding at the end, and gives an excellent foundation that will allow you to build on your Italian skills further down the road.

Yes definitely take italian if you're considering it. It's a great language to learn, well structured, not too much work, and it's honestly fun. Take with Michael Farina if you can, he cares about the class, pushes you, and makes it a fun time.
Yes! The professor was awesome, and a basic knowledge of Italian is good to have
